primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The cosmic liberation of humanity from the ontological power of Death through the creative Word of Christ.

subject.identificatie: Jesus Christ / The Word of God
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus cried with a loud voice, 'Lazarus, come forth!'
Jesus Christ the Son of God steps forward... and speaks
invading the impenetrable darkness... and plundering it

object.identificatie: Life / Resurrection / The 'plundered treasure' of humanity
tekstueel_bewijs: calls into existence the things that do not exist
the same voice that was heard at Creation
children of Israel were patiently taught by God
he who believes in me... shall he live

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The creative power of the Word
tekstueel_bewijs: One with the Creator and the Spirit
by baptism and the Holy Spirit

tegenstander.identificatie: Death / The Devil / The Great Antagonist
tekstueel_bewijs: Death is the living power... which feigns to be God
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Death is treated as a quasi-divine, sovereign power that 'survives all other powers' and requires a cosmic duel to defeat.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human attempt to manage or ignore death through psychologizing or 'Corinthian' optimism.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: Modern Culture / The Corinthian Church
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is a false narrative that attempts to bypass the primary program's necessity (the Cross/Resurrection).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.subject_naar_object: Christ → Plundering the Kingdom of Death

voorbeelden_god_subject: God gives life to the dead.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We pathetic human creatures preen and pose.
Men be so strong that they come to fourscore years.

voorbeelden: sooner or later we must face it
they preferred to think of death as a mere blip
Martha seems to have a clue
Only a Power greater than that of Death can countermand that strict arrest.
God can bring into existence the things that do not exist.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses entirely on the 'Ability' (Pouvoir) of God in the face of the total 'Inability' of man. It is a sermon of pure Divine Capacity.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (The reality of the corpse) to ~S1 (Modern denial) to S1 (The creative Word).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'Infinite Qualitative Distinction'—only the Creator can bridge the gap from S2 to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the 'stink' and 'rigor mortis' are emphasized to make S1 miraculous.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is radically theocentric. Man is the corpse (Receiver); God is the Actor (Subject).

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Did Lazarus have a choice? ... Did the light have any choice?

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Lazarus is not an example to follow, but a specimen of death whom God acts upon.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: Lazarus is the object of God's creative power.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; removal of the burden of self-salvation.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is an act of New Creation, not moral improvement.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative of the 'stinking corpse' perfectly sets up the 'Creative Word'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: invading the impenetrable darkness... and plundering it

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: Endowment of life where there was none.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Death is the 'Supreme Enemy' and 'Last Antagonist'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The Subject-Object relationship is correctly ordered: God acts, Man receives.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; the context of Easter justifies the focus on Power.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in grace-oriented homiletics that refuses to make the hearer the hero of the story.

comparatiele_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric would look at the use of the Emily Dickinson poem, semiotics looks at how the poem establishes the 'Opponent's' power.
comparatiele_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains John 11; semiotics shows how the sermon functions as a 'New Creation' event in itself.
comparatiele_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'stink' of Lazarus is a necessary actantial helper to emphasize the 'Pouvoir' of the Subject (Jesus).

volledige_object_lijst: The things that do not exist
appendices.notities: The sermon utilizes Fleming Rutledge's own criteria perfectly.
